Frischer, Bernard

II CXT - Enabling a 3D Digital Cultural Heritage Pipeline: From Aquisition to Publishing to Archiving

In this proposal, an interdisciplinary research team of computer scientists and domain experts in the humanities will investigate acquisition, archiving, and publication issues pertaining to 3D virtual environments of cultural heritage sites. The long-term objective is to create a center to "Serve and Archive Virtual Environments" (SAVE), which will ultimately exist as an open repository of scientifically authenticated 3D cultural heritage models. The project will create cost-effective tools to more easily capture the data necessary for the creation of the models. Tools for version control and methods for sustainability will be developed. The project's workplan includes:
- development of an innovative 3D acquisition system for efficient, easy creation of 3D models of cultural heritage sites;
- research into archiving and presentation issues for 3D model repositories;
- deployment of a pilot 3D cultural heritage model archive; and,
- implementation of a complete process for editorial review and publication of authenticated 3D models
The resulting 3D archive will made publicly available as an online resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We live in an increasingly 3D world. From Hollywood movies to the design of prosthetic devices and 3D printing, 3D technologies are becoming ubiquitous in our society. This project focused on how new 3D data capture and modeling technologies can be used to study cultural heritage artifacts from the small scale of a statue to the larger scale of a monument or an entire settlement.

Although 3D technologies are now in common use in many industries, they have been too expensive for academics to use in the everyday tasks of teaching and research. Yet 3D digital models of works of art and architecture have the potential to play the same educational role in the twenty-first century that 35 mm slides played in the twentieth. For example, rather than teaching students about Michelangelo’s famous statue of “David” in Florence, Italy, by showing them a photograph, wouldn’t it be more effective to give them a highly accurate 3D model on their computer screen that allows them to explore the statue close up, far away, and from all possible points of view?  If we want to teach students about the now practically vanished Roman Forum in the city center of ancient Rome, wouldn’t it be better to let them experience it through a 3D reconstruction rather than through photographs and dry verbal descriptions of the ruins? And shouldn’t such 3D models be easy to find and use on the Internet?

Our project hoped to help bring the day closer when 3D technologies can be used in these ways by students and scholars of cultural heritage. Our goals were: 

1)         To develop a new 3D acquisition system making it easier to create 3D models of cultural heritage monuments and sites. At the moment, devices used for 3D data of such large objects are expensive, with prices typically running from $50,000 to $150,000. If we can reduce the price with no sacrifice in quality, then it is easy to predict that more and more scholars will take advantage of this powerful technology.

2)         To investigate how 3D models of cultural heritage artifacts can be archived and distributed on the Internet. Until now, most such 3D models are made by individual scholars who are not familiar with strategies for long-term preservation of their work. Moreover, once a 3D model has been created, scholars would like to find a peer-reviewed publication that can distribute it to the scholarly community, but no such publication exists. Wouldn’t more scholars create 3D models of cultural heritage artifacts if there were a high-quality publication outlet so that they could get credit for their work through the normal academic procedures such as hiring, promotion and retention?

To achieve the first goal, we collaborated with Steuart Systems to design and implement a camera array omni-directional 3D data capture device. Progress was made toward realization and commercialization of the camera array omni-directional 3D acquisition device. Steuart Systems developed a continuing series of improved hardware for the device, utilizing the 3D software pipeline and display methods developed through our project.

Regarding the second goal, we researched and designed the architecture of a proposed online journal and digital library for the 3D models. We addressed logistical issues such as organizing an editorial board.  We created a pilot website called "SAVE" (http://idialabprojects.org/save/login.php) as the first step in implementation of a new web service where scientists can publish their 3D models at no cost and with Open Access for the public.
